TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit WebErrorEvent extends System.Web.Management.WebBaseErrorEvent

remarks.format:
## Remarks ASP.NET health monitoring allows production and operations staff to manage deployed Web applications. The <xref:System.Web.Management> namespace contains the health-event types responsible for packaging application health-status data and the provider types responsible for processing this data. It also contains supporting types that help during the management of health events.
The <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> provides information about errors caused by problems with configuration or application code. An example is the error issued by ASP.NET when an error is found in a page.
> [!NOTE] > In most cases you will be able to use the ASP.NET health-monitoring types as implemented, and you will control the health-monitoring system by specifying values in the `healthMonitoring` configuration section. You can also derive from the health-monitoring types to create your own custom events and providers. For an example of deriving from the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> class, see the example provided in this topic.
## Examples The following code example shows how to derive from the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> class to create a custom event.
Also shown is an excerpt of the configuration file that enables ASP.NET to use this custom event.
``` <healthMonitoring enabled="true" heartBeatInterval="0">
<eventMappings>
<add name="SampleWebErrorEvent" type="SamplesAspNet.SampleWebErrorEvent,weberrorevent,Version=1.0.1573.21549, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=2a0b23915ac7352b, processorArchitecture=MSIL"/>
</eventMappings>
<profiles> <add name="Custom" minInstances="1" maxLimit="Infinite" minInterval="00:00:00" /> </profiles>
<rules> <clear />
<add name="Custom Web Error Event" eventName="SampleWebErrorEvent" provider="EventLogProvider" profile="Custom" /> </rules>
</healthMonitoring> ```

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent.%23ctor%2A> constructor is not intended to be used directly from your code. It is called by ASP.NET. You can call the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent.%23ctor%2A> constructor when deriving from the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> class.
## Examples The following code example shows how to customize this constructor.
